headline.main: 'It's All Dust': A Family That Withstood Weeks of War Finally Leaves Kabul

lead_paragraph: A mule crossed the mountains from Afghanistan to the east on Sunday evening. Nadia, seven months pregnant, a schoolteacher who could not work under the rule of the Taliban, rode sidesaddle. Her husband, Dr. Mohammed Azim, walked alongside. Their 18-month-old daughter was in his arms. A saddlebag held their worldly possessions. ''Our home was destroyed by the American bombs -- it's all dust,'' said Dr. Azim, 31, a pediatrician in Kabul until last week. He and his exhausted wife sat in a house in Peshawar hours after their exodus. The house sheltered seven refugee families in seven bare rooms.
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people have been uprooted by seemingly endless misfortunes of Afghanistan; many have not known moment's peace since they were children; in Peshawar, Pakistan, some Afghan refugees describe their arduous journey; photos (M)
